intro: Fraxinus excelsior subsp. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf ash, is a subspecies of the common ash native to Europe. It is a deciduous tree characterized by its slender, elongated leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The leaves are opposite, with a smooth margin and a slightly serrated edge. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in catkins during late spring, followed by winged samaras as its fruit. This subspecies is often found in woodland areas and prefers well-drained soils.
